column1: 0,Industrial_Gas_Turbines_AMY_Razak.txt,147,514e0440d1cfac05494ca5d822f27a7d7ea471d536c4218a7daec7f7b97a7d19,"9.14. The measurements required for a single-shaft gas turbine are as follows:
5. turbine exit temperature (exhaust gas temperature, EGT)
10. variable inlet guide vane/variable stator vane position if applicable.

Single shaft gas turbines are often used in power generation and the gas turbine power output can be determined from the generator output. The total number of fault indices is four and they correspond to the compressor fouling and efficiency fault indices and to the turbine fouling and efficiency fault indices.

A similar approach can be used to determine the fault indices for other engine configurations discussed earlier. For a two-shaft gas turbine operating with a free power turbine the required measurements are:
Initialise all fault indices to zero
Run the engine model at the operating conditions (i.e. run the model at the measured compressor inlet pressure and temperature, turbine exit pressure, power output and VIGV position)

column2: Does the measured EGT match the value from the model?
Adjust the turbine efficiency fault index
Does the compressor exit pressure match the model value?
Adjust the turbine fouling fault index
Does the compressor exit temperature match the model value?
Adjust the compressor efficiency fault index
Does the fuel flow match the model value?
Adjust the compressor fouling fault index

column1: 9.14 Procedure to determine fault indices by comparing the engine measured parameters with those obtained from the model.
# 254 Industrial gas turbines – principles of performance

Note the absence of the power measurement for the case of the two-shaft gas turbine described above. Six fault indices can now be determined for a two-shaft gas turbine operating with a free power turbine. They correspond to the gas generator compressor fouling and efficiency fault index; gas generator turbine fouling and efficiency fault index; and the power turbine fouling and efficiency fault index.

The measurement of specific humidity should also be included, particularly at high ambient temperatures where the change in specific humidity with relative humidity is significant. As discussed in Chapter 2 (Section 2.11.1), a change in specific humidity will have a noticeable affect on the thermodynamic properties of air and products of combustion, hence influencing the engine performance, as shown in Fig. 11.30. ",What are the required measurements for a single-shaft gas turbine according to the text?,"Compressor inlet temperature, compressor inlet pressure, compressor exit temperature, compressor exit pressure, turbine exit temperature (EGT), turbine exit pressure, fuel flow, gas turbine speed, gas turbine power output, and variable inlet guide vane/variable stator vane position if applicable.","The text lists 10 measurements: compressor inlet and exit temperatures and pressures, turbine exit temperature and pressure, fuel flow, speed, power output, and VIGV/VSV position.","For a single-shaft gas turbine, measurements include temperatures and pressures at compressor and turbine exits, fuel flow, speed, power output, and VIGV position.","Required measurements: 1) compressor inlet temperature, 2) compressor inlet pressure, 3) compressor exit temperature, 4) compressor exit pressure, 5) EGT, 6) turbine exit pressure, 7) fuel flow, 8) speed, 9) power output, 10) VIGV/VSV position.","The text specifies measurements like compressor and turbine temperatures and pressures, alongside fuel flow, speed, power, and VIGV position for single-shaft turbines."

5. turbine exit temperature (exhaust gas temperature, EGT)
10. variable inlet guide vane/variable stator vane position if applicable.

",What is the procedure to determine fault indices by comparing engine measured parameters with model values?,"Initialize fault indices to zero, run the engine model at operating conditions, and adjust indices based on mismatches between measured and model values for EGT, compressor exit pressure, compressor exit temperature, and fuel flow.","The procedure involves initializing indices, running the model, and adjusting indices for turbine efficiency, turbine fouling, compressor efficiency, and compressor fouling based on discrepancies.","Start with zero indices, compare measured parameters like EGT and fuel flow with model outputs, and adjust relevant fault indices accordingly.","Steps: 1) initialize indices, 2) run model at measured conditions, 3) adjust indices based on EGT, compressor exit pressure and temperature, and fuel flow mismatches.",The text outlines a method where fault indices are adjusted after comparing actual measurements with model predictions for key parameters.

",What are the differences in fault indices between single-shaft and two-shaft gas turbines?,"Single-shaft turbines have four fault indices (compressor and turbine fouling and efficiency), while two-shaft turbines have six, adding power turbine fouling and efficiency.",Two-shaft turbines include two additional indices for power turbine fouling and efficiency compared to single-shaft turbines.,"The text shows single-shaft turbines have four indices, whereas two-shaft turbines have six, covering power turbine aspects as well.",Differences: single-shaft has compressor and turbine indices; two-shaft adds power turbine fouling and efficiency indices.,"Single-shaft turbines' indices cover compressor and turbine, while two-shaft turbines' also include power turbine fouling and efficiency."
